He is now a religious man after suffering an accident where he lost an eye. He hopes to invest his money in fertilizer and seeds for the fields. He is a very hard worker who saves in order to one day send his son to college.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice Farming

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng C. is 35 years old, married and a mother of 3 children, who are students. She makes her living by selling Khmer noodles and porridge along the roadside of her village and typically makes a meager profit. To service the family's expenses, her husband is both a construction worker and a farmer who normally makes about $4/day. Meanwhile,  C. is asking for $300 in order to purchase a piece of land to grow a variety of crops. With this, she hopes her family will make more income to increase the family's savings. It is important to say that her family would like to own another piece of land to increase her crops for the next coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land to grow crops

loans.name: Ing

texts.en: Mrs. Ing Sarim is a 35 year old widow, with two chldren who are both students. Currently she makes $8 a day by making and selling beef soup. She would like to use the loan to increase the amount of beef soup she can make so as to meet growing customer demand.

loans.use: to invest in her shop

loans.name: Yudelka Yanelis

texts.en:
Yudelka, 29, and her husband sell clothes for women and children, in order to earn a living and take care of their own seven children. Yudelka started the business five years ago. She buys in Santo Domingo, the capital, and retails the clothes in her community. Right now the couple is running the business out of their modest rented house in Hato Nuevo.

Yudelka is now working to expand the business and make it known to all the community and sell more. She is planning to renovate a small locale that her husband has just bought for her and move the business there. She also wants vary her range of products, adding clothes for men to her business.

The couple needs straightaway a loan that could help them reach their purpose and increase their income so that they can improve the situation of their needy family.

loans.use: To renovate a small locale as to move her business; also to introduce men's clothes to vary her inventory

loans.name: Mili Piedad

texts.es:
Mili Piedad belongs to the Communal Bank of Lumbreras of the District of Calleria of the Department of Ucayali. She is 25 years old and has two sons. Her husband is a lumberjack. With the first loan from Manuela Ramos, she wants to start a small stand for selling cookies and candy.

She currently has one stand, which she runs with her sons. She takes a lot of time to look after them and tend to the warehouse.

With this recent loan from Manuela Ramos of $367.00, which will be paid in four months, she will make improvements in her shop and will buy three boxes of milk, two sacks of rice, two sacks of sugar, five boxes of soda, and one drum of oil.

Mili Piedad is very happy to have her business in her own house which allows her to also look after her children.

Translated from Spanish by David Hou, Princeton University Language Project volunteer.

La señora Mili Piedad pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Lumbreras, del A. H. Jr. Las Begonias del A. H. Odicio Roman del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 25 años y es madre de 2 hijos, su esposo es maderero. Con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 100.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto para la venta de galletas y golosinas.

En la actualidad cuenta con una bodega, la misma que atiende junto a sus hijos, ella se da tiempo para atenderlos y también atender la bodega

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, hará mejoras en su local y comprará 3 caja de leche, 2 saco de arroz, 2 saco de azúcar, 5 cajas de gaseosa, 1 bidón de aceite.

Mili Piedad está muy contenta de tener su negocio en su misma casa lo que le permite también atender a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of various products. Business infrastructure.

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Mr. Adama K. is 35 years old, married and the father of 4 children. He is the owner of a general store situated in the center of town. He has been managing this activity for almost 5 years and has been a client of FECECAV for 2 years. He has already obtained 2 loans, which he repaid in full. This current loan will allow him to increase his store because of the ever increasing demand.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Mr Adama K. est agé de 35 ans marié et père de 4 enfants. Il est propriétaire de la boutique d'alimentation générale implantée au centre ville. Elle gère cette activité depuis bientôt 5 ans et est client de FECECAV depuis 2 ans. Il a déjà eu deux crédits qu'il remboursé sans défaut. Le présent emprunt va lui permettre d'accroître sa boutique à cause de la demande sans cesse croissante de la demande.

loans.use: Bulk purchase of 85 bags of rice, 20 jugs of oil, and 30 bags of sugar in Lomé to be sold in Kpalimé

loans.name: Acholi D Group

texts.en:
Eva is 40 years old and divorced with three children. All the children are going to school. Eva, Florence and Winfred all have stone quarrying businesses.With the extra business profits, Eva wants to save money for her children's education because she wants her children to have good quality education. Lamulasi has a retail shop and intends to use th loan to purchase more products.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more land for stone quarrying

loans.name: Muguluka West A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ziyada K.. She is currently in the business of selling sugar wax and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Ziyada is 39 years old and is married. Her husband has a maize milling business. She has 6 children ranging from age 6 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Ziyada makes approximately UGX 23000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate the children and invest more into her business. Ziyada has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 350000 in order to boost the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Ziyada is joined in her small group by Florence N., Rose W., Zaituni K., and Saida N.. Florence N. has a business in used clothing sales and wants to increase working capital. Rose W. is currently operating a business selling cold soft drinks and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Zaituni K. operates a business selling sugar wax and wants to boost business. Saida N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase the stock of items.

loans.use: To add to sugar business and expand it

loans.name: Vilma's Group

texts.es:
Vilma and Marline have been members of the Tarpuy Communal Bank for 5 years now. "Tarpuy" means "seed" in quechua, an indigenous language in Peru. Vilma is a happy 35 year old mother of 3 children. She buy cereals from the Playa Grau market and sends them to her sister, who sells them in the rainforest.

Marline is 38 years old, married, and has 5 children. She sells food every morning out of the Nery García Zarate market. She also sells firewood out of her home.

Vilma and Marline need respective loans of 1000 and 600 soles ($575 total), money that will be invested in the purchase of peas, beans, wheat, cereals and firewood. They will use their savings to buy some land, build a house, and educate their children. Vilma and Marline share common dreams. They would each like to have their own house someday. They each wish to see their children working in the professional sector. Lastly, they would like to finish building their home and open a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer

Vilma y Marline pertenecen al Banco Comunal Tarpuy que significa “Siembra” en quechua hace 5 años.

Vilma es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Vilma compra cereales del mercado Playa Grau y lo envía a su hermana para que lo venda en L. selva ayacuchana.

Mientras que Marlinees casada, tiene 38 años y 5 hijos, Marline venD. comida todas las mañanas en el mercado Nery García Zarate D. manera ambulatoria. Además Marline venD. leña en su casa.

Vilma y Marline necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles y 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. arveja, haba, trigo, cereales procesados y leña.

Sus ahorros lo utilizarán para comprar un terreno, construir su casa y para L. titulación D. su hija. Los sueños D. Vilma y Marline son tener casa propia, que sus hijos sean profesionales, construir L. segundo piso D. su casa y tener una tienda D. abarrotes.

loans.use: Purchase of peas, beans, wheat, cereal and firewood

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en: My name is Jameela A.. I am married and a mother of eight: four boys and four girls. I reside with my family in Lahore, Pakistan. My husband is a daily wage laborer and I sew bags. I have been sewing bags for the last 25 years. I would like to acquire a loan from Kiva to further expand my business. My loan group members are: Fatima Asghar (who is borrowing for her butcher shop), Yasmeen (who also sews bags) and Safia B. (who trades used items).

loans.use: to expand my bag stitching business

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en:
Tarana M., 35, runs her own business raising cows. She started her business in 1998 and since that time, her main financial resource has been selling milk and yoghurt. As meat is very popular all across Azerbaijan and selling calves could bring her good income, she has expanded her business activity from selling milk to also raising calves.

Tarana is married and lives with her family in a setlement for internally displaced persons in the Bilasuvar region. She and her husband are unemployed and it is very hard for them to cover their family's needs with their low monthly income.

To improve their situation, Tarana has applied for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase one cow at an estimated cost of US$ 600 and two calves at US$ 200 each.

loans.use: to purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua D. sells smoked fish in Kumasi. She is single, and her income must fully support her and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for $400 of additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Konotieyele (La Lumière De L’Oiseau Male) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Konotieyele group are married women, aged 38 and with 7 children on average. They live in polygamous families with their husbands and children in the village of Konobougou, Sub-Prefecture of Baroueli (Ségou Region, Republic of Mali).

The principal business activity of these women of the Konotieyele group (so named in memory of the founder of the village: male bird Diarra) is the sale of firewood and charcoal which they buy from farmers (supplying the village of Konobougou) who have a permit to cut wood. They have storerooms in their husbands’ compounds and generally sell charcoal retail to a local clientele (women, men) and wholesale to buyers who come out to the country from the big towns like Ségou and Bamako.

United by ties of profession and neighborhood and very active in economic activities, the members of the group are requesting their third group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, having repaid prior loans correctly. With this loan they intend to buy 80 sacks of charcoal and 5 loads of firewood and hope to make an average monthly profit of 35000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, to pay for family necessities, and above all bolster their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Konotieyele sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 38 ans et 7 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris et enfants dans le village de konobougou sous préfecture de Baroueli (Région de Ségou République du Mali)

L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes Konotieyele(en mémoire au fondateur du village konotiè :oiseau male Diarra) est la vente du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois, qu’elles achètent avec les paysans (ravitaillant le village de Konobougou) et qui détiennent des permis de coupe de bois. Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage dans la concession conjugale et vendent généralement le charbon de bois en détail à une clientèle locale (femmes hommes) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou et Bamako.

Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage et très entreprenants dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec un remboursement correct. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 80 sacs charbon de bois et 5 chargements de bois de chauffe et espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35000FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et surtout renforcer leurs activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of charcoal and diverse items for re-sale

Achat de charbon ce bois et d’articles divers

loans.name: Naimdjon

texts.en: Naimdjon D. is 21 years old, single, and has been in the business of selling cell phone accessories such as chargers, earphones and cases for the last two years. His business is located in the central market of Khujand City. Naimdjon runs his business very skillfully and has great prospects for growing it in the future. This year is crucial for Naimdjon because he plans to be married soon. To raise his income and support his new status as a husband, he is planning to expand his business and buy more accessories to sell. To make this possible, he is seeking a $600 loan which he will pay back in 12 months He promises to repay the loan in a timely manner and thanks everyone for their  support, which will help him tremendously and make his wedding possible.

loans.use: To buy additional cell phone accessories to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sitri

texts.id: Sebagai seorang ibu rumah tangga Ketut Sitri tergolong wanita yang ulet. Selain membantu suaminya Wayan Lungguh bekerja sebagai petani, Ketut Sitri juga memelihara babi di belakang rumahnya. Setelah bergabung di kelompok Kembang Mekar dan mengajukan pinjaman pertama ke DINARI, Ketut membeli satu ekor induk babi disamping 3 ekor bibit penggemukan yang sudah dimilikinya. Selain itu sisa pinjaman juga digunakan untuk membeli pakan babi. Setelah 5 bulan dipelihara Ketut menjual anak-anak babi dari induk peliharaanya dan berhasil mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 200.000,- per bulannya. Itu belum termasuk keuntungan dari penjualan 3 ekor babi penggemukan modalnya sendiri. Selanjutnya pada pinjaman kedua dengan jangka waktu sama yaitu 6 bulan, Ketut akan menambah 4 ekor bibit penggemukan dan tetap memelihara induknya juga. Nantinya dengan penambahan populasi babi ini akan diperoleh hasil yang lebih bagus lagi dari sebelumnya sehingga pinjaman DINARI juga bisa dikembalikan pada akhir periode pinjaman dan bisa segera dilanjutkan lagi dengan pinjaman selanjutnya. Karena hasil dari beternak babi ini sangat menjanjikan bagi Ketut Sitri dalam meningkatkan perekonomian keluarganya.
texts.en:
Ni Ketut Sitri is a very diligent housewife. Besides helping her husband, Wayan Lungguh farming, Ketut Sitri also owns a pig farm in her backyard. Fater joining Kembang Mekar group and sought first loan from DINARI, Ketut bought a pig. She previously has farmed 3 pigs. The loan was also used to buy feeds. After 5 months, the matured and fattened pigs were sold for $20 net profit per months. She is seeking second loan with 6 month tenor to purchase 4 piglets. Hopefully with these additional pigs, she cna earn more profit to pay back the loan and bring additional profitt to help her family's finances.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Piglets and Feeds

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.es:
Edgardo tiene una hijo de de 5 años; quien actualmente se encuentra hospitalizado debido a que padece de leucemia. El inició el negocio para seguir estudiando y sacar adelante a su hijo, el cual constantemente requiere hospitalización, medicina y cuidado, debido a que es papa soltero no tenia quien le ayudara a cuidarlo, decidió emprender un negocio, que le permitiera cuidar a su hijo y fue esa la causa de que empezara a trabajar, consiguió una carreta y empezó a elaborar y vender hot- dogs y tortas trabajando primero solo los fines de semana y después e empezó a instalar todos los días afuera de las maquiladoras y gasolineras.

El necesita un préstamo por US $425 que pagara en 6 meses para poder remodelar la carreta ya que ocupa pintura además de que cuenta con muy poco mobiliario y muchos de sus clientes batallan cuando están comiendo, así que con este prestamos podrá adquirir nuevas mesas acompañadas de sus sillas y podrá brindar un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Edgardo has a 5 year-old son who is presently hospitalized as he has leukemia. Edgardo started his business in order to continue his studies and give his son a good start in life as he constantly needs hospitalization, medicine, and care. As a single father he had nobody to help him take care of his son so he decided to start a business that would allow him to look after him and that was the reason he began to work, got a wagon and started to make and sell hot-dogs and sandwiches, at first on week-ends and afterwards daily in front of assembly plants and gas stations.

Edgardo needs a loan of $425 to be repaid in 6 months to remodel the wagon, as it needs paint and has very few furnishings, making it difficult for clients to eat, but with the loan he will buy new tables and chairs thus being able to offer more comfort.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Remodel wagon used for business.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: Isabel tiene 35 años, convive con su pareja, con la cual tuvo tres hijos: Yaquelin de 14, Káterin de 10 y Arnol de 6. Trabajando desde muy joven y teniendo que apoyar en la economía del hogar, decidió hace 6 años dedicarse al servicio de llamadas por celular, actividad que le da buenas ganancias, ya que se desplaza por diferentes lugares en su afán de conseguir más clientela. Lo complicado es tener que cumplir  con su labor de madre, apoyando a sus hijos con sus tareas y deberes y tener que salir a trabajar, teniéndolos que dejar muchas veces solos y no pudiendo estar ahí cuando la necesitan, pero su trabajo es lo que les da educación vestimenta y cuida de su salud, es así que Isabel, se siente feliz de realizarlo. Este es su primer préstamo en microfinanzas PRISMA. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar otro celular y ponerlo a trabajar, para poder mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Isabel is 35 years old and lives with her husband and three children: Yaquelin of age 14, Katerin of age 10, and Arnol of age 6. She has worked since she was very young and now has to financially support her family. Consequently, she decided to make a living providing cellular phone services for the past six years. This endeavor earns good profits because she goes to different places in her effort to gain more customers. The biggest complication is to fulfill her motherly duties, such as supporting her children with their homework and chores, because she has to work. She has to leave them alone often and cannot be there for them when they need her. However, it is her job that provides them with school clothing and keeps them healthy, and Isabels feels fortunate to realize this reality. This loan is her first with microfinanzas PRISMA. With the requested money, she would like to buy another cellular phone and put it to work in order to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase another cellular phone for her call center business

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
After eight years of settling in Ballacong, Lilibeth observed that their village is continually developing in terms of livelihood, road condition, and education, but many poor families are still striving to fight poverty. 

Their village is an agricultural area where different vegetables, roots crops, corn, rice, watermelon etc. are planted. Lilibeth’s husband is a government employee with a modest monthly income. In order to help him provide for their family’s needs and for the education of their two children, Lilibeth opened a business selling and e-loading (adding prepaid minutes) mobile phones.

The growing demands for e-loading motivated her to go into this type of business. Lilibeth enjoys the business, because selling loads to distant areas helps to connect people all over the world. However, due to the increasing demands on mobile phone loads, she does not have enough capital to purchase the thousands of load wallets she needs to satisfy her daily customers.

She is asking for a loan of Php5, 000 which will be sufficient for her to be able to expand her business.

“Though their life is very tough, they do not lose hope and continue to dream on,” Lilibeth shares. She and her husbandwill work hand in hand to make their two children become good people who have good attitudes and are disciplined. Their ultimate dream is to be able to send their children  to college to have a brighter future.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Gema

texts.es:
La señora Gema, socia del BC “MUJERES AUDACES”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, se dedica a la venta de comida tipo menú y su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa, lugar donde diariamente acuden gran cantidad de clientes por la buena sazón y trato que les brinda. 

Con este crédito de S/ 3,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará insumos como arroz, azúcar en saco, aceite en galón, fideos y otros que necesita para la preparación de sus platos a ofertar a sus clientes. También quiere hacer algunos arreglos a su local como pintarlo y comprar mesas y sillas.

Gema es una mujer perseverante y muy amigable, tiene 39 años de edad, vive con sus dos hijos, quienes la impulsan a esforzarse cada día más y con su esposo. Desea para el futuro contar con un recreo turístico y vender comidas típicas de la región.
texts.en:
Gema, a member of the communal bank, Bold Women, lives in the San Martin region, in the province and district of Moyobamba. She sells meals out of her own home, a place where a large number of customers visit every day for the great seasoning (in the food) and the good service that Gema offers. With this loan of $1,000, which will be paid back in six months, she will buy ingredients like rice, sacks of sugar, gallons of cooking oil, pasta, and other things that she needs to prepare her meals to offer her customers. She also wants to do a few things around her house/business, such as paint it and buy tables and chairs. Gema is a persevering woman and very friendly. She is 39 years old and lives with her two children who inspire her to work hard every day. She also lives with her husband. In the future, she would like to have tourism-related business and sell food typical to the region.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, pasta, and other ingredients

loans.name: Primera De Samuel Group

texts.es: Las integrantes del GRUPO SOLIDARIO FRATERNIDAD viven en el barrio Ricardo Rivera de la ciudad de Diriomo tuvieron la oportunidad de aprobar la primaria lo que les permite ser unas personas bien comunicativas y accesibles en la sociedad. Iniciaron sus negocios ambulantes, vendiendo ropa de forma ambulante. La Señora Araceli del Carmen L. junto a su grupo ha logrado obtener 2 créditos con Adim, tiene pocos meses de trabajar pero la experiencia ha sido muy buena porque ella recibe confianza y siente que debe de responder igual y así lo expresa a su grupo y anima a que sigan con excelente comportamiento, está esperando a asistir a una capacitación a la que está invitada y tiene deseos de salir adelante. Ella vende ropa usada y nueva, en su casa exhibe la ropa usada y la nueva solo la lleva por encargos de sus clientes, cada vez tiene más encargos, tiene dos niños pequeños que ella misma los cuida. Está muy orgullosa de poder tener un negocio y ser reconocida por esto y así el nivel de vida de sus hijos ha mejorado notablemente. Sus créditos lo utilizan en la compra de pacas de ropa seleccionada y así ofrecer un mejor producto a su clientela.
texts.en:
The members of the group “Fraternity and solidarity” live in the Ricardo Rivera neighborhood of the city of Diriomo, Nicaragua. They had the opportunity to finish primary school, which has allowed them to be communicative and accessible people in society. They started their businesses as walking saleswomen, selling their clothes as they walked the streets. Mrs. Araceli del Carmen L., along with her group, has received two previous credits from Kiva field partner ADIM. Araceli has only a few months of work experience, but it has been very good because it has given her confidence and she feels that she should respond equally. That’s how she expresses it to her group and encourages them to continue with their excellent work. She is hoping to attend a training to which she has been invited, and she wants to move forward. She sells new and used clothes. She displays the used clothing in her home, but she carries new clothing solely based on client orders. Her orders are continually growing. She has two small children that she takes care of herself. She is very proud to be able to have a business and be recognized for it, and her children’s quality of life has improved notably because of it. The requested loan will be used to purchase selected clothing in bulk so that she can offer better products for her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase varied clothing to sell to clients

loans.name: Koemsrean

texts.en:
Mr. Koemsrean Y., 28, and his wife, Mrs. Sophea Kong, 24, were married in 2008 and have no children. The couple lives with their parents and brothers and sisters in a small village across Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Koemsrean and his wife have been raising pigs for three months. Beside raising pigs they also produce rice wine and grow rice. Koemsrean is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to purchase feed for raising pigs and growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase feed for raising pigs.

loans.name: Ortikboy

texts.ru:
Ортикбой мужчина 49 лет , отец шестерых детей,мастер по стройке домов.У Ортикбоя своя бригада, в которой он бригадир.Жена работает в колхозе.Ортикбой дополнительно занимается откормом и продажей скота.
Ортикбой хорошо разбирается в породистых баранах.У него сейчас около 30 баранов,которые все хорошей породы.Ортикбою по бизнесу помогают его семья,дети.В связи с дождями Ортикбой хочет получив кредит заменить крышу хлева ,где он держит свой скот.
texts.en:
Ortikboy is a 49 year old man, the father of six children, and a home construction specialist. Ortikboy is the leader of a construction team, and his wife works on a collective farm. He also raises and sells livestock on the side. Ortikboy is knowledgeable about purebred sheep. He has around 30 rams, which are all well bred. His family also helps with the business. Because of rain, Ortikboy wants to obtain a loan to replace the roof of the barn where the sheep are kept.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Feed and sale of livestock

loans.name: Leitu

texts.en: Leitu A., 56, is married with five children. She has less than one year of experience in a donuts business. She will sell her donuts to school children and village people five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $200 USD). SPBD loans are Leitu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients needed to start her donut business, such as sacks of flour, sugar, oil, yeast and an oven.

loans.use: To buy ingredients such as sacks of flour, sugar, cooking oil, yeast and an oven to start her donut business.

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
La señora Santos R. D. G. tiene 62 años, vive en Saucipe, distrito D. Paijan,  provincia D. Ascope, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió hasta 2do D. secundaria, no continuo estudiando debido a que sus padres no la quisieron apoyar. Tiene 09 hijos y ninguno depenD. D. ella económicamente.
Santos se dedica a la venta D. tejidos y la crianza D. animales, inició su negocio hace 18 años criando patos y pavos al mismo tiempo que tejía colchas y conjuntos para bebes, con el tiempo su negocio ha ido creciendo y sus animales los venD. en Trujillo, así como teje a pedido, con las ganancias que a obtenido empezo el negocio D. siembra D. maíz y espárrago en sociedad con su esposo, su negocio lo desarrolla en su domicilio.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su banco comunal “Manos Unidas”, lo invirtió en la compra D. patos.   
Con el crédito D. 1100 soles, que será cancelado en  6 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra D. patos, pollos, pavos y alimento balanceado.
Santos sueña con terminar D. construir su casa.
texts.en:
Mrs. Santos R. D. G. is 62 years old. She lives in Saucipe, Paijan district, Ascope province, department of La Libertad, Perú. She studied until the second year of secondary school but didn't continue because her parents did not want to support her. She has nine children and none of them depend on her financially.

Santos sells woven fabrics and raises animals. She started her business 18 years ago raising ducks and turkeys and at the same time she wove colchas (woven fabrics used as bedspreads, rugs, etc.) and outfits for babies. Her business has grown with time. She sells her animals in Trujillo and takes orders for her weavings. With her earnings she started a business planting corn and asparagus with her husband. Their business is located in their home.

With the first loan of 300 Peruvian nuevo soles that she received from her Communal "Manos Unidas" ("United Hands), she invested in buying ducks. With the loan of 1100 soles, which will be paid back in 6 months, she will invest in buying ducks, chickens, turkeys and animal feed. Santos dreams of finishing the construction on her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ducks, chickens, turkeys, and animal feed

loans.name: Ann Adhiambo

texts.en:
Ann Adhiambo O. is the 30-year-old mother of one four-year-old child who just started school. She is married to a man who works in Milymani Resort, a hotel in the nicest part of Kisumu that has a 60s era art-deco swimming pool. To supplement her husband’s income, she sells vegetables and tomatoes in Kasawino, which is next to the Nyamasaria slum.

Right now, she makes around 1500 Kenyan Shillings (about US $19) in profit a week. Ann hopes to expand her business and wants the loan to buy more Irish potatoes, Sukumawiki and rice. If she cannot make a larger profit, she will use the loan to pay for her child’s school fees. She is asking for 10,000 shillings.

Ann recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Foods for resale or school fees

loans.name: Dil Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Dil Maiya M. is a resident of Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming.
Mrs. M. lives in a single family with her husband and three sons. Her husband, Mr. Ram Chandra, is a driver. Her older two sons are studying in higher level and younger son is in primary school.
Mrs. Dil Maiya M. is a beautician. She has completed the beautician training. Now she wants to open her own beauty salon, but due to a lack of funds, she cannot open her own beauty salon. Mrs. M. is requesting an Rs 20000.00 loan to open her own beauty salon. She wants to open the beauty salon to uplift the economic condition of her family.

loans.use: To open a beauty salon

loans.name: María Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora María S. se dedica a su negocio de venta de productos diversos ofrecidos en su propia pulpería la cual ha logrado manejar y sacar adelante gracias a sus esfuerzos por mejorar el negocio.

Ella es una dama que ha logrado aprovechar los créditos brindados por Ceprodel y hoy en día una vez más acude para ser beneficiada con un nuevo crédito que le permita la compra de dichos productos para ofertarlos en la pulpería y de esta manera contribuir al bienestar de su amada familia que tiene que mantener.
texts.en:
María S. dedicates herself to the her business in the sale of various products offered in her small grocery store, which she has been able to manage and continue expanding thanks to her efforts to improve the business. She is a woman who has been able to take advantage of the loans offered by Ceprodel and now she again seeks a new loan that will allow her to purchase products to offer in her small grocery store; in this way she will contribute to the well-being of her beloved family who she has to support.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products

loans.name: Miriam Herlinda

texts.es:
Miriam es socia del Banco Comunal Los Claveles.
Miriam es conviviente, tiene 30 años y 3 hijos, Miriam tiene una tienda de repuestos en un local alquilado, mientras que su esposo tiene un taller mecánico en el mismo lugar y Miriam es quien le provee de repuestos.
Miriam necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de repuestos y lubricantes.
Los sueños de Miriam son implementar el taller de su esposo con todas las maquinarias y sus hijos estudien en buenos colegio.
texts.en:
Miriam is a member of the Los Claveles (The Carnations) Communal Bank. She is living with her domestic partner, is 30 years old and has three children. Miriam has a parts store in a rented space, while her spouse has a mechanic's workshop in the same location and Miriam provides him with his parts. Miriam needs a loan of 1,600 Sols which will be used to buy parts and lubricants. Her dreams are to equip her husband's shop with all the necessary equipment, and that her children will study at a good high school.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy parts and lubricants.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora María Guadalupe C. tiene ya más de cinco años dedicándose a la venta de ropa usada, zapatos y juguetes. 
Es la fuente de ingreso que tiene para darle lo mejor a sus dos pequeños hijos que tiene ya que es madre soltera. 
Al negocio le está haciendo falta más variedad de mercancía y quiere también vender ropa nueva, pero no tiene el capital necesario para la inversión y no quiere descapitalizar el negocio. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para poder surtir el negocio y así tener más ingresos para su familia y un parte para pagar el crédito.
texts.en:
María Guadalupe C. has been working more than 5 years selling used clothes, shoes, and toys. It is the source of income she has to give the best she can to her two young children as she is a single mother. At her business she needs a greater variety of merchandise and she also wants to sell new clothes, but she doesn’t have the necessary capital for the investment and she doesn’t want to reduce the business’s net worth. Because of this she is asking for a loan to be able to supply the business and therefore have a greater income for her family and be able to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta C. is from the village of Pinansalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Julieta is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish and seafoods to local community members. Julieta earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Julieta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used for repair and maintenance of her pumpboat. This will be the third loan taken out by Julieta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for repair and maintenance of pumpboat

loans.name: Olayiwola

texts.en: Olayiwola is 36 years old and married with a child. She has a shop where she sells medicine. She has been in this business for the past 18 years. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medical drugs to sell

loans.name: Sentongo's Group

texts.en: N. Sentongo is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 42 years and married with 5 children aged between 22 – 12 years as she cares for other siblings. She is a business lady involved in the sale of agricultural produce in Lugazi Central market for 15 years. Mostly she sells tomatoes and cabbages which she started so small with a few bags of the produce but now has more with a possibility of making 100,000/= a week due to her quality produce and the ability of her sellers to pay in time. She also wants to join another business by owning a retail shop in future and later move into a wholesale department. She needs a loan to be able to add more capital into her agricultural produce selling business since this widens the supply of her produce.

loans.use: Buying tomatoes and cabbages and at times matooke for resale.

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Airene S. is from the village of Lingating, Baungon Bukidnon. She is 20 years old. Airene is single and has one infant child. To make a living, Airene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Airene has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Airene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Airene is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Airene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Huon

texts.en: Farming rice is part of 30-year-old Huon M.’s daily routine. Rice is a necessary product vital to Cambodian people. She learned to do this from her grandmother and she is very widely known in this sector since before she was married. Her husband, Svay Pheng, assists her with the farm work and he appears in the photograph. In addition, Huon M.’s husband also spends time on the river for a fishing activity. This couple lives with two children who attend school and also work on the farm. Huon M. will be using the loan to buy fertilizer and seed to facilitate rice-growing. With the remainder of loan she will buy a fishing tool to supply her husband business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed to facilitate rice-growing

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina manages a sari-sari store (community based store) in their village. She is married to Aldrin and their family resides in the village of Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. They have six children; the eldest is now in second year high school, while the others are in elementary level.  Gina wants them to finish their studies in college so that they will find a good jobs in the future. 

Gina and her husband are doing their best to earn a living and support the schooling of their children. She usually purchase her products in the public market of Solano. Every week, she can earn a gross income of P 1,500.00 which she uses to acquire their daily basic needs and finance the schooling of their children. Since education nowadays is very costly, she needs to earn more income to finance the schooling of their children. To improve her business, she is now asking for a loan amounting to PHP5,000.  She is hoping that the more products she will sell, the more income she will earn.

loans.use: Additional capital in the improvement of her small variety store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is already 45 years old. She manages a snacks and food vending business and also sells some grocery items at her stall. Her weekly net income is Php500. Wanting to increase her income, she planned to have a loan of Php5,000 from KIVA lenders as additional working capital for her business.

Elizabeth is married to a driver named Romeo and they are blessed with six children namely: Sheila – 23 years of age, a plain housekeeper, Michael - 22 years of age, a security guard in Manila, Carla - 21 years of age, Melvin 18 years of age, a college student taking up Development Communication, Joboy 16 years of age, a senior high school student, and their youngest Mary Camille -7  years of age, a grade I student. 

They reside at Barangay Mozzozzin Norte, Sta.Maria Isabela. Elizabeth hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan to sustain her family needs and most especially for the continued productivity of her business.

loans.use: additional capital for her food vending business

loans.name: George Charo

texts.en:
George Charo N. is a 35-year old man married to Jumwa, who is a housewife. Together they have four children between the ages of 11 and 2 years. They live in Chakama, which is a few kilometers from Malindi.

George has been farming for ten years. He gets a monthly profit of 2,500 Kenyan shillings (KES) from his farm and he also works as a watchman providing security in Chakama. He is taking out his second loan from KADET. With this loan, he plans to buy three gallons of petrol and a water pump to boost his crop output. With the extra earnings from this loan he hopes to invest in a retail shop and in his childrens' education.

George describes himself as a focused and hardworking person and dreams of building a permanent house for his family and expand his farming activities.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a water pump and 3 gallons of petrol.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim L., 51, is married and lives with her six children in Siem Reap province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$15 in revenue each day, while her husband grows vegetables and makes US$7 a day.

Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high.

Kim L. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike to transport groceries.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her groceries

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
D. Ilhomjon is 28 years old. He is married with two children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuff like cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, and tea in his grocery store which he built five years ago. Today Ilhomjon is requesting a loan of 4500 Somoni. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children will progress by means of their studies, for which Ilhomjon is working hard. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of the foodstuffs for a small grocery store.

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Tania es socia del Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga.
Tania es soltera, tiene 37 años y 1 hijo, Tania tiene un taller de confección de prendas de vestir en un local alquilado, actividad que inicio hace 1 año en asociación con su hermana, Tania tiene proyectado hacer uniformes y buzos para la campaña escolar.
Tania necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas.
Los sueños de Tania son tener una empresa de confecciones y contar con un local propio.
texts.en:
Tania is a member of the Alegría Huamanga Community Bank. She is single, 37 years old and has one son. Tania has a sewing shop making clothes at a rented site, an activity she started one year ago along with her sister. Tania plans to make uniforms and sweatshirts for the school season. She is requesting a loan of 2,000 soles (approximately $700), which she plans to invest in the purchase of fabrics. Her dream is to have a larger sewing business on a space she owns.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabrics

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn T. is a 37-year-old villager in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is the mother of three children; two attend a local public school, while one helps her do housework. 

Mrs. Phorn T. is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice, and is also a Khmer cake maker to support her family. She has some problems with her rice field because the soil is infertile. Thus, Mrs. Phorn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers.  With the rest of the loan she will buy rice seeds, pesticides, fuel, and hire a laborer to plow the field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for a rice field

loans.name: Asif

texts.en:
Asif M. is 26 years old and a very enthusiastic young man who has been selling different kinds of domestic goods since 2005. Asif is single but responsible for supporting his parents who are unemployed. His shop is the only source of income in Asif's family but the income that his shop brings him is not enough to build his own family. 

Asif believes one day he will have a big family with many children. For this purpose Asif applied for a loan in the amount of 1600 AZN, as he believes this loan will help him to increase his profit. Let’s do our best to help this hard-working man.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to increase profit

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en: Ginalyn started farming way back in 2002.  She said she started with a small amount of capital so her harvest was not really that much.  Having two children, she and her husband work hard to supply their growing needs.  Ginalyn is seeking additional capital from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs.  Hopefully, this loan would help Ginalyn achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A., currently in the business of designing and selling bedsheets, is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets and designs to sell.  Agnes,  31 years old and married to a businessman, is the mother of three children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine for easier design work.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bedsheets and designs to sell

loans.name: 02.09.04 Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en: Dan L. T. (209016) is a 42-year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang Hoa, Thanh Hoa. Dan is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02,09,04 Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa (02.09.04 Hoang Hoa). Dan is married and has four school-aged children. She operates a business planting and harvesting rice for saL.. She has been engaged in this business for over eighteen years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month. In 2003, Dan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Dan is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her 7th from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. C. T. Toi (209017) is a 51-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising crops. 2. C. T. Thuy (209021) is a 29-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 3. N. T. Thang (209022) is a 49-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising crops. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Dan L. T. (209016) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa. Dan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02,09,04 Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa (02,09,04 Hoang Hoa). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ trồng & thu hoạch gạo để bán. Dan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 18 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Dan kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND. Vào 2003, Dan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Dan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua hạt giống bổ sung, cây giống & cây con để trồng. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. C. T. Toi (209017) là 51 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. 2. C. T. Thuy (209021) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 3. N. T. Thang (209022) là 49 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en:
Warlito A. is from the village of Olango. He is 45 years old. Warlito is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Warlito owns & operates an agriculture business, earning income from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Warlito has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 28000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Warlito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Warlito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Warlito is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Warlito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as reserve funds for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Semira

texts.en:
Semira M. makes and sells local brew and wines at home and is requesting a loan to also stock crates of beer to sell.  Semira is 32 years-old and is married with a husband that is a businessman. She has three children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en: Nodira is a devoted mother who struggles day after day to provide the best for her family. Eight years ago she got the idea to start raising cattle to contribute to the family finances, taking advantage of the space she had available on their land for this business. She is engaged in this business together with her husband. Slowly the number of cows increased and, with the increase, her clients started asking for more and more. With an endless list of requests, she has finally decided to increase the number of livestock she keeps and for this reason is requesting a loan. Be an important part of the growth of Nodira’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle and calves to expand her business

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is 39 years old, married and has six children who range in age from 5 to 15.  All are currently attending school. He lives in the western Kenyan town of Kitale town, where he has been a farmer for 14 years and now has two employees. His most important products are milk, maize and beans, all of which he sells in the local market. His biggest challenges are diseases that affect his crops and changes in the price of milk.

Philip has applied for a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes 62,400 to buy and insure a cow that will increase the amount of milk he can sell to his customers.  He will use the extra income to meet his family's basic needs. He is a strong supporter of Juhudi Kilimo and hopes it will continue to reach out to small scale farmers so that they can expand economically.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chhoeung

texts.en: Mrs. T. is a 49-year-old widow and is the mother of five children. Four of them are now married and live separately and the other one is single. T. currently stays at home to sell a few produce items in her small store in front of her home. She sells such wares as cooking ingredients, cakes, and some vegetables to people in the village. In order to earn additional income and to make her business more successful, T. is applying for a loan to add to her working capital and increase her inventory.

loans.use: To add to her working capital and her inventory

loans.name: Florevel

texts.en:
Florevel S. is from the village of Pta. Miray, Baliangao. She is 30 years-old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Florevel owns and operates a business fish selling. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Florevel has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. She is also engaged in the retail sector running a general store.

In 2001, Florevel joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florevel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Florevel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in her general store. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Florevel from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. is single. She has no formal education. Esi sells saucepans, plastic bows and other things in Abura. She has been doing this for two years. Esi uses her income to pay for her accommodation and utility bills. Esi will use this loan to purchase more cooking utensils and plastic products for resale. Esi plans to save the new earnings from her extended trade to buy a shop where she can display her goods.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking utensils and plastic products for resale

loans.name: Hilda Senayda

texts.es:
la sra. Hilda Senayda M. L. tiene 57 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Rafael L. quien se dedica 
a la compra venta de ganado, maiz, sal etc. 
Tienen tres hijos que dependen de ellos.
doña Hilda muy dedicada a su familia y a su negocio que es la venta de lacteos al por mayor
y al detalle, sus ventas son diarias.el credito lo utilizara para comprar queso oriado, queso seco, queso semiseco, queso ahumado, quesillo, requeson, mantequilla.
 
su mayor deseo es que sus ventas sean mejores cada dia para a si tener mejores ganancias, las cuales las necesita para cubrir con los gastos de su hogar y de su familia.
texts.en:
Hilda Senayda M. L. is 57 years old. She is married with Rafael L., a merchant of cattle, corn and salt. They have three children and they are all still dependent on them. Hilda is very dedicated to her family and to her business. She sells dairy products in wholesale and retail. She carries out her sales daily. The loan will be used to purchase cheese, and butter. Her greatest wish is to see an improvement in her sales and have better earnings. She will use these earnings to cover the household expenses and to care for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cheeses and butter.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase firewood and baking tools

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is married and has three children. She has been through junior high school.

Ama prepares banku (a local dish made from corn dough and served hot with soup) at Elmina. Her husband is a trader. She uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Ama will use the loan to purchase more maize to prepare more banku for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to establish a banku shop where people can sit comfortably to enjoy their food.

loans.use: To purchase more maize to prepare more banku for sale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 45 years old. She is married to Mr. Anaclito, who works as a driver, and they have one daughter, Joan, a 10-year-old grade school student. 

She joined ASHI because she wanted to have her own business, since her husband's income is not enough to sustain the daily needs of their family. She will use her loan of 10,000 PHP in her buying and selling of different small goods. Specifically, the loan fund will be used to pay for inventories of goods to sell. 

She and her husband aim to use KIVA loans to develop a stable business so they can support the education of their only daughter and have their own beautiful home.

loans.use: to pay for inventories of goods to sell

loans.name: Sabina Ignacia

texts.es: Sabina es una mujer multifacética se dedica  a la elaboración y comercialización de queso, además se dedica  a la ganadería también  labora para el gobierno local como operaria de mantenimiento, tiene 3 hijos jóvenes a quienes ayuda en sus estudios, su sueño es comprarse una casa en la zona de Chosica y a seguir ayudando a sus hijos, como buena hija tiene a su cargo a sus padres ancianos. Con el dinero del préstamo comprara alimento concentrado para sus animales, sabina desea en algún momento tener capital para iniciar un negocio nuevo que le permita estar en casa como una bodega propia.
texts.en: Sabina is a woman of many talents. She makes and sells cheese, she is a cattle farmer, and she also works as a maintenance operator for the municipal government. She has 3 young children that she supports as they go to school. And as a good daughter she cares for her elderly parents. The funds from this loan will be used to purchase concentrated feed for her livestock. Sabina wishes to accumulate enough capital funds to start up a new business. She wants to have a business that she will be able to run while she’s at home, such as a grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase concentrated feed for her livestock.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson K. K. is 30 years old, married, and has one child aged eleven years old and one who is six years old. His business is located at Jomvu estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian ocean's white beaches. He has been rearing and selling chickens to the local people and hotels. He has been in this business for the last four years. He says that this business is profitable, and the major challenge he has is lack of enough capital and the risk of diseases that could kill all the chicks. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more chicks to expand his business. He hopes to grow this business and even diversify into the cosmetics business. He sees himself owning a car some day. He describes himself as hardworking, God-fearing, and welcoming.

loans.use: To buy more chicks to raise.

loans.name: Margaret Nyambura

texts.en:
Margaret has practiced farming in Olkalou town since 2007.  She is a 30-year-old single mother of two children. She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount as capital to start selling shoes.  She already has a shop which she has been using to sell her farm produce such as potatoes.

In future, Margaret hopes to grow the shoe business and become a leading shoe retailer in Olkalou town.

loans.use: To start selling shoes

loans.name: Miraluna

texts.en:
Miraluna S. is from the village of Kauswagan. She is 48 years old, married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Miraluna owns & operates a  a fishing business. The main source of income for the business is harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Miraluna has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Miraluna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Miraluna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Miraluna is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Miraluna's 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gaudencio

texts.en:
Gaudencio O. is a 59-year-old married man who supports his family through his business of buying and selling livestock.  He lives in Badian, Cebu.  He has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved his living conditions with the help of his loans from NWTF and through his own efforts. 

By working hard in his livestock  business, Gaudencio is gradually making his family more economically stable. He now earns an average monthly income of PHP7,000. Gaudencio is borrowing PHP 12,000 to  fund his business operations. This will be his ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. His previous loan of PHP10,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey towards economic freedom. Gaudencio aspires to elevate his family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through this program, NWTF is empowering people to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rio Lindo Group

texts.es:
